bash

2. Backend Setup (Express + Prisma + TS)

Install dependencies

bash
cd backend
npm init -y
npm install express cors dotenv
npm install @prisma/client
npm install -D typescript ts-node-dev @types/express @types/node prisma
npx tsc --init

Example schema.prisma

prisma
datasource db {
  provider = "postgresql"
  url      = env("DATABASE_URL")
}

generator client {
  provider = "prisma-client-js"
}

model User {
  id       Int     @id @default(autoincrement())
  email    String  @unique
  name     String?
  createdAt DateTime @default(now())
}

Example index.ts

ts
import express from "express";
import cors from "cors";
import dotenv from "dotenv";
import { PrismaClient } from "@prisma/client";

dotenv.config();
const prisma = new PrismaClient();
const app = express();

app.use(cors());
app.use(express.json());

app.get("/", (req, res) => res.send("API Running 🚀"));

app.get("/users", async (req, res) => {
  const users = await prisma.user.findMany();
  res.json(users);
});

app.listen(4000, () => console.log("Backend running on port 4000"));

3. Frontend Setup (React with Vite Example)

bash
cd frontend
npm create vite@latest . -- --template react-ts
npm install

Example: Fetching from backend (src/App.tsx)

tsx
import { useEffect, useState } from "react";

function App() {
  const [users, setUsers] = useState<any[]>([]);

  useEffect(() => {
    fetch("http://localhost:4000/users")
      .then(res => res.json())
      .then(setUsers);
  }, []);

  return (
    <div>
      <h1>Users</h1>
      <ul>
        {users.map(u => <li key={u.id}>{u.email}</li>)}
      </ul>
    </div>
  );
}

export default App;

5. docker-compose.yml

This connects backend, frontend, and database (Postgres):

yaml
version: "3.9"

services:
  postgres:
    image: postgres:15
    container_name: postgres_db
    restart: always
    environment:
      POSTGRES_USER: user
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: password
      POSTGRES_DB: mydb
    ports:
      - "5432:5432"
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data

  backend:
    build: ./backend
    container_name: backend_app
    restart: always
    ports:
      - "4000:4000"
    environment:
      DATABASE_URL: postgres://user:password@postgres:5432/mydb
    depends_on:
      - postgres

  frontend:
    build: ./frontend
    container_name: frontend_app
    restart: always
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    depends_on:
      - backend

volumes:
  postgres_data:

6. Running the Stack

bash
docker-compose up --build

  • Frontend → http://localhost:3000

  • Backend → http://localhost:4000

  • Postgres inside Docker → localhost:5432

7. Docker Concepts (Quick Summary)

  • Dockerfile → Instructions for building your app’s container image.

  • docker build → Turns Dockerfile into an image.

  • docker run → Runs container from image.

  • docker-compose.yml → Defines & orchestrates multi-container apps (frontend + backend + db).

  • Volumes → Persist database data across restarts.

🔹 2. Production Setup for Backend (Express + Prisma)

Update your backend Dockerfile to build optimized production image:

dockerfile
FROM node:18-alpine AS build

WORKDIR /app

COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm install

COPY . .

RUN npx prisma generate
RUN npm run build   # compiles TS → JS

# --- Final production image ---
FROM node:18-alpine

WORKDIR /app

COPY --from=build /app/package*.json ./
RUN npm install --omit=dev  # only install production deps

COPY --from=build /app/dist ./dist
COPY --from=build /app/prisma ./prisma

CMD ["node", "dist/index.js"]

✅ This ensures your backend runs compiled JS instead of ts-node-dev.

🔹 3. Production Setup for Frontend (React/Vite with Nginx)

Change frontend Dockerfile:

dockerfile
# Build stage
FROM node:18-alpine AS build

WORKDIR /app
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm install
COPY . .
RUN npm run build   # creates /dist folder

# Nginx stage
FROM nginx:1.25-alpine

# Copy React build → Nginx html folder
COPY --from=build /app/dist /usr/share/nginx/html

# Copy custom Nginx config (optional)
COPY nginx.conf /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf

EXPOSE 80
CMD ["nginx", "-g", "daemon off;"]

Create nginx.conf inside frontend/:

nginx
server {
  listen 80;

  root /usr/share/nginx/html;
  index index.html;

  location / {
    try_files $uri /index.html;
  }

  # Proxy API requests to backend
  location /api/ {
    proxy_pass http://backend:4000/;
  }
}

👉 Notice proxy_pass http://backend:4000/; — this way, your frontend and backend talk inside Docker network, no need for localhost:4000.

🔹 4. Update docker-compose.yml for Production

yaml
version: "3.9"

services:
  postgres:
    image: postgres:15
    container_name: postgres_db

    environment:
      POSTGRES_USER: user
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: password
      POSTGRES_DB: mydb
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    networks:
      - app_net

  backend:
    build: ./backend
    container_name: backend_app
    restart: always
    environment:
      DATABASE_URL: postgres://user:password@postgres:5432/mydb
      PORT: 4000
    depends_on:
      - postgres
    networks:
      - app_net

  frontend:
    build: ./frontend
    container_name: frontend_app
    restart: always
    ports:
      - "80:80"   # expose frontend on host
    depends_on:
      - backend
    networks:
      - app_net

volumes:
  postgres_data:

networks:
  app_net:
    driver: bridge

🔹 5. Running in Production

bash
docker compose up --build -d

  • Frontend (React build via Nginx) → http://localhost

  • Backend (Express) → http://localhost/api (proxied by Nginx)

  • Database (Postgres) runs inside Docker and is accessed by backend via postgres://...

🔹 6. How Backend Finds the Database

Inside docker-compose.yml, we used service name postgres.
So in backend .env:

env
DATABASE_URL="postgresql://user:password@postgres:5432/mydb?schema=public"

👉 Docker DNS resolves postgres to the right container, so backend ↔ DB works even though DB is isolated in Docker Desktop.

🔹 2. Database Models (Prisma)

In schema.prisma:

prisma
model User {
  id              Int      @id @default(autoincrement())
  name            String?
  email           String   @unique
  password        String
  accountType     AccountType
  role            Role?            // only for org accounts
  organizationId  Int?
  organization    Organization?    @relation(fields: [organizationId], references: [id])
  createdAt       DateTime @default(now())
}

model Organization {
  id        Int      @id @default(autoincrement())
  name      String   @unique
  link      String   @unique
  users     User[]
  createdAt DateTime @default(now())
}

enum AccountType {
  PERSONAL
  ORGANIZATION
}

enum Role {
  OWNER
  ADMIN
  MEMBER
}

🔹 3. Middleware (Auth)

backend/src/middleware/auth.ts

ts
import { Request, Response, NextFunction } from "express";
import jwt from "jsonwebtoken";

export interface AuthRequest extends Request {
  user?: any;
}

export const authMiddleware = (req: AuthRequest, res: Response, next: NextFunction) => {
  const token = req.headers.authorization?.split(" ")[1];
  if (!token) return res.status(401).json({ error: "No token provided" });

  try {
    const decoded = jwt.verify(token, process.env.JWT_SECRET!);
    req.user = decoded;
    next();
  } catch (err) {
    return res.status(403).json({ error: "Invalid token" });
  }
};

🔹 4. Controllers

auth.controller.ts

ts
import { Request, Response } from "express";
import bcrypt from "bcryptjs";
import jwt from "jsonwebtoken";
import { PrismaClient } from "@prisma/client";

const prisma = new PrismaClient();

// --- Signup ---
export const signup = async (req: Request, res: Response) => {
  const { name, email, password, accountType, organizationName, organizationLink, role } = req.body;

  try {
    const hashedPassword = await bcrypt.hash(password, 10);

    if (accountType === "PERSONAL") {
      const user = await prisma.user.create({
        data: { name, email, password: hashedPassword, accountType: "PERSONAL" }
      });
      return res.json({ message: "Personal account created", user });
    }

    if (accountType === "ORGANIZATION") {
      let org = null;

      if (organizationName) {
        // create new org
        org = await prisma.organization.create({
          data: { name: organizationName, link: organizationLink }
        });
      } else {
        org = await prisma.organization.findUnique({ where: { link: organizationLink } });
        if (!org) return res.status(400).json({ error: "Organization not found" });
      }

      const user = await prisma.user.create({
        data: {
          name,
          email,
          password: hashedPassword,
          accountType: "ORGANIZATION",
          role: role || "MEMBER",
          organizationId: org.id
        }
      });

      return res.json({ message: "Organization account created/joined", user });
    }
  } catch (err) {
    return res.status(500).json({ error: "Signup failed", details: err });
  }
};

// --- Login ---
export const login = async (req: Request, res: Response) => {
  const { email, password, organizationLink } = req.body;

  try {
    const user = await prisma.user.findFirst({
      where: { email, ...(organizationLink ? { organization: { link: organizationLink } } : {}) },
      include: { organization: true }
    });

    if (!user) return res.status(400).json({ error: "User not found" });

    const valid = await bcrypt.compare(password, user.password);
    if (!valid) return res.status(401).json({ error: "Invalid password" });

    const token = jwt.sign(
      { id: user.id, role: user.role, accountType: user.accountType, orgId: user.organizationId },
      process.env.JWT_SECRET!,
      { expiresIn: "1d" }
    );

    return res.json({ message: "Login successful", token, user });
  } catch (err) {
    return res.status(500).json({ error: "Login failed", details: err });
  }
};

// --- Logout ---
export const logout = async (req: Request, res: Response) => {
  // if using JWT, just tell client to delete token
  return res.json({ message: "Logout successful. Please discard token." });
};

🔹 6. Role-Based Access Middleware (optional)

middleware/roles.ts

ts
import { AuthRequest } from "./auth";
import { Response, NextFunction } from "express";

export const requireRole = (roles: string[]) => {
  return (req: AuthRequest, res: Response, next: NextFunction) => {
    if (!req.user || !roles.includes(req.user.role)) {
      return res.status(403).json({ error: "Forbidden" });
    }
    next();
  };
};

Example usage:

ts
router.get("/admin-only", authMiddleware, requireRole(["ADMIN", "OWNER"]), (req, res) => {
  res.json({ message: "Welcome Admin/Owner" });
});

✅ With this setup:

  • Personal signup/login just needs name/email/password.

  • Organization signup can create or join org.

  • Roles are enforced with middleware.

  • JWT-based authentication keeps it stateless and secure.

🔹 4. Auth Context (global user state)

src/context/AuthContext.tsx

tsx
"use client";
import { createContext, useContext, useState, ReactNode, useEffect } from "react";
import { useRouter } from "next/router";
import api from "../lib/api";

type User = {
  id: number;
  email: string;
  accountType: "PERSONAL" | "ORGANIZATION";
  role?: "OWNER" | "ADMIN" | "MEMBER";
};

interface AuthContextType {
  user: User | null;
  token: string | null;
  login: (email: string, password: string, organizationLink?: string) => Promise<void>;
  signup: (data: any) => Promise<void>;
  logout: () => void;
}

const AuthContext = createContext<AuthContextType | undefined>(undefined);

export function AuthProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) {
  const [user, setUser] = useState<User | null>(null);
  const [token, setToken] = useState<string | null>(null);
  const router = useRouter();

  const login = async (email: string, password: string, organizationLink?: string) => {
    const res = await api.post("/auth/login", { email, password, organizationLink });
    setToken(res.data.token);
    setUser(res.data.user);
    router.push("/dashboard");
  };

  const signup = async (data: any) => {
    const res = await api.post("/auth/signup", data);
    setUser(res.data.user);
    router.push("/dashboard");
  };

  const logout = () => {
    setToken(null);
    setUser(null);
    router.push("/login");
  };

  return (
    <AuthContext.Provider value={{ user, token, login, signup, logout }}>
      {children}
    </AuthContext.Provider>
  );
}

export function useAuth() {
  const ctx = useContext(AuthContext);
  if (!ctx) throw new Error("useAuth must be inside AuthProvider");
  return ctx;
}

🔹 6. Login Page

src/pages/login.tsx

tsx
import { useState } from "react";
import { useAuth } from "../context/AuthContext";

export default function LoginPage() {
  const { login } = useAuth();
  const [accountType, setAccountType] = useState<"PERSONAL" | "ORGANIZATION">("PERSONAL");
  const [email, setEmail] = useState("");
  const [password, setPassword] = useState("");
  const [organizationLink, setOrganizationLink] = useState("");

  const handleSubmit = async (e: React.FormEvent) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    await login(email, password, accountType === "ORGANIZATION" ? organizationLink : undefined);
  };

  return (
    <div className="min-h-screen flex items-center justify-center bg-gray-100">
      <form onSubmit={handleSubmit} className="bg-white shadow-md rounded-xl p-6 w-96 space-y-4">
        <h2 className="text-xl font-semibold">Login</h2>

        <select
          value={accountType}
          onChange={(e) => setAccountType(e.target.value as any)}
          className="border rounded p-2 w-full"
        >
          <option value="PERSONAL">Personal</option>
          <option value="ORGANIZATION">Organization</option>
        </select>

        {accountType === "ORGANIZATION" && (
          <input
            placeholder="Organization Link"
            value={organizationLink}
            onChange={(e) => setOrganizationLink(e.target.value)}
            className="border rounded p-2 w-full"
          />
        )}

        <input
          placeholder="Email"
          value={email}
          onChange={(e) => setEmail(e.target.value)}
          className="border rounded p-2 w-full"
        />
        <input
          placeholder="Password"
          type="password"
          value={password}
          onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)}
          className="border rounded p-2 w-full"
        />

        <button className="bg-blue-600 text-white w-full py-2 rounded-lg hover:bg-blue-700">
          Submit
        </button>
      </form>
    </div>
  );
}

🔹 7. Signup Page

src/pages/signup.tsx

tsx
import { useState } from "react";
import { useAuth } from "../context/AuthContext";

export default function SignupPage() {
  const { signup } = useAuth();
  const [accountType, setAccountType] = useState<"PERSONAL" | "ORGANIZATION">("PERSONAL");
  const [role, setRole] = useState<"OWNER" | "ADMIN" | "MEMBER">("MEMBER");
  const [name, setName] = useState("");
  const [organizationName, setOrganizationName] = useState("");
  const [organizationLink, setOrganizationLink] = useState("");
  const [email, setEmail] = useState("");
  const [password, setPassword] = useState("");
  const [confirmPassword, setConfirmPassword] = useState("");

  const handleSubmit = async (e: React.FormEvent) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    if (password !== confirmPassword) return alert("Passwords do not match");

    await signup({
      accountType,
      name,
      email,
      password,
      organizationName: accountType === "ORGANIZATION" ? organizationName : undefined,
      organizationLink: accountType === "ORGANIZATION" ? organizationLink : undefined,
      role: accountType === "ORGANIZATION" ? role : undefined,
    });
  };

  return (
    <div className="min-h-screen flex items-center justify-center bg-gray-100">
      <form onSubmit={handleSubmit} className="bg-white shadow-md rounded-xl p-6 w-96 space-y-4">
        <h2 className="text-xl font-semibold">Signup</h2>

        <select
          value={accountType}
          onChange={(e) => setAccountType(e.target.value as any)}

🔹 3. Role-Based Middleware Update

middleware/roles.ts

ts
export const requireRole = (roles: string[]) => {
  return (req: AuthRequest, res: Response, next: NextFunction) => {
    if (!req.user || !roles.includes(req.user.role)) {
      return res.status(403).json({ error: "Forbidden" });
    }
    next();
  };
};

🔹 3. Role-based Redirect After Login

src/pages/login.tsx

tsx
import { useRouter } from "next/router";
import { useAuth } from "../context/AuthContext";

export default function LoginPage() {
  const router = useRouter();
  const { login } = useAuth();

  async function handleLogin(e: React.FormEvent<HTMLFormElement>) {
    e.preventDefault();
    const form = new FormData(e.currentTarget);
    const email = form.get("email") as string;
    const password = form.get("password") as string;

    const success = await login(email, password);

    if (success) {
      const user = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem("user") || "{}");

      if (user.accountType === "PERSONAL") {
        router.push("/dashboard/personal");
      } else if (user.accountType === "ORGANIZATION") {
        if (user.role === "OWNER" || user.role === "ADMIN") {
          router.push("/dashboard/admin");
        } else if (user.role === "MEMBER") {
          router.push("/dashboard/member");
        } else if (user.role === "CLIENT") {
          router.push("/dashboard/client");
        }
      }
    }
  }

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleLogin} className="max-w-md mx-auto p-6 space-y-4">
      <h1 className="text-xl font-bold">Login</h1>
      <input name="email" type="email" placeholder="Email" className="border rounded p-2 w-full" />
      <input name="password" type="password" placeholder="Password" className="border rounded p-2 w-full" />
      <button type="submit" className="w-full bg-blue-600 text-white rounded p-2">Login</button>
    </form>
  );
}

🔹 5. Protecting Routes by Role

Optional: add a wrapper withAuth HOC so only correct roles access their dashboards.

tsx
import { useAuth } from "../context/AuthContext";
import { useRouter } from "next/router";
import { useEffect } from "react";

export function withRole(Component: React.FC, allowedRoles: string[]) {
  return function ProtectedPage() {
    const { user } = useAuth();
    const router = useRouter();

    useEffect(() => {
      if (!user) {
        router.push("/login");
      } else if (!allowedRoles.includes(user.role)) {
        router.push("/unauthorized");
      }
    }, [user]);

    if (!user) return null;

    return <Component />;
  };
}

Example usage:

tsx
export default withRole(AdminDashboard, ["ADMIN", "OWNER"]);

  • Unauthorized access blocked with middleware.

1. Account Creation Flow (register)

Your current register already supports PERSONAL, ORGANISATION, and LINK.
👉 I’ll clean it up a little and enforce approval rules.

ts
// src/controllers/auth.controller.ts

export const register = async (req: Request, res: Response) => {
  try {
    const {
      name,
      email,
      password,
      passwordConfirm,
      mode, // "PERSONAL" | "ORGANIZATION" | "LINK"
      organizationName,
      organizationSlug,
      role,
    } = req.body;

    if (!name || !email || !password || !passwordConfirm) {
      return res.status(400).json({ message: "Missing required fields" });
    }
    if (password !== passwordConfirm) {
      return res.status(400).json({ message: "Passwords do not match" });
    }

    const existing = await prisma.user.findUnique({ where: { email } });
    if (existing) return res.status(400).json({ message: "User already exists" });

    const passwordHash = await bcrypt.hash(password, 12);

    let accountType: AccountType;
    let assignedRole: UserRole;
    let organizationId: string | null = null;
    let isApproved = true;

    /** PERSONAL FLOW */
    if (mode === "PERSONAL") {
      accountType = AccountType.PERSONAL;
      assignedRole = UserRole.PERSONAL;

    /** ORGANIZATION CREATION FLOW */
    } else if (mode === "ORGANIZATION") {
      accountType = AccountType.ORGANIZATION;
      if (!organizationName) {
        return res.status(400).json({ message: "organizationName required" });
      }

      const creatorRole = String(role || "OWNER").toUpperCase();
      if (!["OWNER", "ADMIN"].includes(creatorRole)) {
        return res.status(400).json({ message: "Creator must be OWNER or ADMIN" });
      }

      // slugify
      const slugBase = (organizationSlug || organizationName).trim().toLowerCase().replace(/\s+/g, "-");
      let slug = slugBase;
      let i = 1;
      while (await prisma.organization.findUnique({ where: { slug } })) {
        slug = `${slugBase}-${i++}`;
      }

      const org = await prisma.organization.create({
        data: { name: organizationName, slug },
      });
      organizationId = org.id;
      assignedRole = creatorRole as UserRole;
      isApproved = true; // creator auto-approved

    /** JOIN EXISTING ORG FLOW */
    } else if (mode === "LINK") {
      accountType = AccountType.ORGANIZATION;
      if (!organizationSlug) {
        return res.status(400).json({ message: "organizationSlug required" });
      }

      const org = await prisma.organization.findUnique({ where: { slug: String(organizationSlug) } });
      if (!org) return res.status(404).json({ message: "Organization not found" });

      organizationId = org.id;

      const roleUpper = String(role || "MEMBER").toUpperCase();
      if (!Object.values(UserRole).includes(roleUpper as UserRole)) {
        return res.status(400).json({ message: "Invalid role for LINK mode" });
      }

      assignedRole = roleUpper as UserRole;
      // approval only for MEMBER or CLIENT
      isApproved = ["OWNER", "ADMIN"].includes(assignedRole);

    } else {
      return res.status(400).json({ message: "Invalid mode" });
    }

    // Create user
    const user = await prisma.user.create({
      data: {
        name,
        email,
        passwordHash,
        role: assignedRole,
        accountType,
        isApproved,
        organizationId,
      },
    });

    // Create membership if organization
    if (accountType === AccountType.ORGANIZATION && organizationId) {
      await prisma.membership.create({
        data: {
          userId: user.id,
          organizationId,
          role: assignedRole,
          status: isApproved ? MembershipStatus.APPROVED : MembershipStatus.PENDING,
        },
      });
    }

    return res.status(201).json({
      message: "Account created",
      user: {
        id: user.id,
        email: user.email,
        role: user.role,
        accountType: user.accountType,
        isApproved: user.isApproved,
      },
    });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("register error", err);
    return res.status(500).json({ message: "Internal server error" });
  }
};

3. Approval Workflow

  • MEMBER and CLIENT accounts go in with MembershipStatus.PENDING.

  • An ADMIN or OWNER can later approve them via an approveMember controller, e.g.:

ts
export const approveMember = async (req: Request, res: Response) => {
  try {
    const { membershipId } = req.body;

    const updated = await prisma.membership.update({
      where: { id: membershipId },
      data: { status: MembershipStatus.APPROVED },
    });

    await prisma.user.update({
      where: { id: updated.userId },
      data: { isApproved: true },
    });

    return res.json({ message: "Member approved", membership: updated });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("approve error", err);
    return res.status(500).json({ message: "Internal server error" });
  }
};

organizationId,

status: isApproved ? MembershipStatus.APPROVED : MembershipStatus.PENDING,

},

});

}

}

ChatGPT can make mistakes. Check important info.
